channel.title: California
channel.description: California news and features from the Los Angeles Times.

item.title: USC to remove John Wayne exhibit after student protests over racist comments the actor made decades ago
item.dc:creator: Tomás Mier
item.description: The exhibit housed at the School of Cinematic Arts led to student protests in September 2019.
item.content:encoded: The exhibit housed at the School of Cinematic Arts led to student protests in September 2019.

media:content.media:description: The USC School of Cinematic Arts includes film directors Bryan Singer and Juss Apatow and showrunner Shonda Rhimes among its alumni.

item.title: California to release 8,000 prisoners in hopes of easing coronavirus crisis
item.dc:creator: John Myers, Phil Willon
item.description: The announcement on Friday by top advisors to Gov. Gavin Newsom offered stark evidence of the dire health conditions at several California prisons.
item.content:encoded: The announcement on Friday by top advisors to Gov. Gavin Newsom offered stark evidence of the dire health conditions at several California prisons.

media:content.media:description: A cellblock at San Quentin State Prison in April. More than 80 inmates became sick with pneumonia during an outbreak of Legionnaire's disease. The bacteria was traced to the prison medical building.

item.title: Independent autopsy of Robert Fuller finds no signs of foul play
item.dc:creator: Matthew Ormseth
item.description: An independent autopsy commissioned by the family of Robert Fuller, a Black man whose body was found hanging from a tree in Palmdale, found no signs of foul play, the family's attorney said Friday.
item.content:encoded: An independent autopsy commissioned by the family of Robert Fuller, a Black man whose body was found hanging from a tree in Palmdale, found no signs of foul play, the family's attorney said Friday.

media:content.media:description: LITTLE ROCK, CA - JUNE 30: Pallbearers carry Robert Fuller's casket to the hearse in Living Stone Cathedral of Worship on Tuesday, June 30, 2020 in Little Rock, CA. According to the Los Angeles County Sheriff's Department, a passerby found Mr. Fuller's body hanging from a tree across from Palmdale City Hall on June 10. Initially, the death was ruled a suicide, but the family stated that Mr. Fuller was not suicidal. (Dania Maxwell / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Bill Field, organist and founder of Old Town Music Hall, dies at 80
item.dc:creator: Steve Marble
item.description: For more than half a century, Field supplied the music and magic at El Segundo's old-school movie house.
item.content:encoded: For more than half a century, Field supplied the music and magic at El Segundo's old-school movie house.

media:content.media:description: Bill Field seated at the Wurlitzer

item.title: Long Beach police still looking for shooters in Halloween party attack that left 3 dead
item.dc:creator: Hannah Fry
item.description: Long Beach officers found victims inside and outside the home. Nine people were taken to area hospitals. Three were pronounced dead at the scene.
item.content:encoded: Long Beach officers found victims inside and outside the home. Nine people were taken to area hospitals. Three were pronounced dead at the scene.

media:content.media:description: Family and friends of shooting victims are joined by government officials on Nov. 5 during a traditional Buddhist memorial ceremony in the backyard of a home in Long Beach where three people were killed Halloween night.

item.title: 3 LAPD officers charged with falsifying records to claim people were gang members, associates

item.title: Half of California counties now on state watchlist as coronavirus infections surge
item.dc:creator: Luke Money
item.description: As infections surge, California's coronavirus watchlist now includes counties from virtually every corner of the state.
item.content:encoded: As infections surge, California's coronavirus watchlist now includes counties from virtually every corner of the state.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - JULY 08: Walk-ins wait for Coronavirus Covid-19 testing in LA County at the Charles R. Drew University of Medicine and Science in South Los Angeles on July 8, 2020 as California records its highest single-day coronavirus death toll with 149 fatalities reported. The Charles R. Drew University site has tested a large number of people from racial and ethnic minority groups that are at higher risk for poor outcomes and complications from COVID-19. Drew University on Wednesday, July 8, 2020 in Los Angeles, CA. (Al Seib / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Coroner: Andres Guardado was shot 5 times in the back, died of gunshot wounds
item.dc:creator: Alene Tchekmedyian
item.description: L.A. County coroner's office determines that Andres Guardado, the 18-year-old killed by an L.A. County sheriff's deputy, was shot 5 times in the back.

(Jason Armond / Los Angeles Times)

media:content.media:description: COLTON, CA - JULY 8, 2020: An ICU nurse, middle, wearing a CAPR (Controlled Air Purifying Respirator) enters a negative pressure room to treat a COVID-19 patient at Arrowhead Regional Medical Center on July 8, 2020 in Colton, California. This ICU has only 2 more beds available for Covid patients, but has the capacity to expand to more beds if needed.(Gina Ferazzi / Los Angeles Times)

item.content:encoded: Officials are hoping public behavior changed toward the end of June and early July, but they won't know how that plays out for several more weeks.

media:content.media:description: ORANGE, CA - JUNE 18: A man wearing a mask and driving a vintage VW Bug at the Orange Circle on Thursday, June 18, 2020 in Orange, CA. Gov. Gavin Newsom on Thursday ordered all Californians to wear face coverings while in public or high-risk settings due to coronavirus. Orange County recently did not require face mask to be worn. (Gary Coronado / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Op-Ed: Why is UC San Francisco threatening to destroy a monument to California's Black history?
item.dc:creator: Jackie Broxton and Kevin Waite
item.description: Why would UC San Francisco destroy a Depression-era mural depicting a former slave turned midwife?
item.content:encoded: Why would UC San Francisco destroy a Depression-era mural depicting a former slave turned midwife?

media:content.media:description: *** LICENSED FOR ONE-TIME USE ONLY FOP OP-ED JULY 2020 *** A mural panel featuring African American midwife Biddy Mason commissioned for UC Hall at UC San Francisco in the 1930s. The 10-panel mural depicting California medical history was painted by Bernard Zakheim. The university plans to demolish the hall and the mural panels, unless financial support can be found to save the artwork. (Mandatory credit: Chris Carlsson)

item.content:encoded: The main teachers union for LAUSD said distance learning should continue until it is safe to resume in person.

media:content.media:description: SAN FERNANDO, CA-APRIL 20, 2020: LAUSD Superintendent Austin Beutner, left, walks with principal Flora Mendoza-Werner during a tour of one of the district's Grab & Go food centers at San Fernando Senior High School, where meals were given out to LAUSD students in need. They are wearing protective masks against the spread of the coronavirus. (Mel Melcon/Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Coronavirus hospitalizations jump 97% in Orange County in less than a month
item.dc:creator: Hannah Fry
item.description: The increase has prompted hospitals in the region to begin to prepare for a surge of sick patients, according to the director of the Orange County Health Care Agency.
item.content:encoded: The increase has prompted hospitals in the region to begin to prepare for a surge of sick patients, according to the director of the Orange County Health Care Agency.

media:content.media:description: SANTA ANA, CA - JULY 07: Pedestrians wearing masks cross Main Street on 4th Street in downtown Santa Ana on Tuesday, July 7, 2020. Orange County Health Care Agency officials Monday reported 1,028 new coronavirus cases, the most ever, but some infections date back to June 18 due to a backlog of reporting from the state. Orange County Sheriff Barnes is sparring with Gov. Newsom over enforcement of masks order. Santa Ana has the highest number of recorded cases. (Allen J. Schaben / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Temperature checks and hotels: Newsom details new precautions for wildfire evacuations

item.description: Gov. Gavin Newsom warned Californians about growing wildfire dangers and described changes to evacuation protocols to prevent the spread of COVID-19.
item.content:encoded: Gov. Gavin Newsom warned Californians about growing wildfire dangers and described changes to evacuation protocols to prevent the spread of COVID-19.

media:content.media:description: Mandatory Credit: Photo by PETER DASILVA/EPA-EFE/REX (9973331h) Evacuees gather at The Neighborhood Church evacuation shelter in Chico, CA, as it continues to burn through the region, fueled by high winds in Butte County, California, USA, 10 November 2018. The nearby communities of Pulga, Paradise and Concow, have been ordered to evacuate the area. Butte County wildfire and evacuations, USA - 10 Nov 2018 ** Usable by LA, CT and MoD ONLY **

item.title: Yolo County businesses face $10,000 fines for ignoring coronavirus safety rules
item.dc:creator: Kailyn Brown
item.description: Fines can range from $250 to $10,000 for businesses in Yolo County, depending on the "gravity of public health risk posed by the violation," and individuals can be fined from $25 to $500.
item.content:encoded: Fines can range from $250 to $10,000 for businesses in Yolo County, depending on the "gravity of public health risk posed by the violation," and individuals can be fined from $25 to $500.

media:content.media:description: Barbara Meier, right, wears a face mask as picks up her drink order from Philz Coffee in Davis, Calif., Monday, April 27, 2020. Yolo County, where Davis is located, now requires people to wear face masks in public. Face coverings are not required at home, alone in a car, outdoors, walking, hiking bicycling or running. (AP Photo/Rich Pedroncelli)

item.title: Gardena security guard charged with murder after fight with customer over mask

item.description: Jerry Lewis, a popular 1990s rapper known by the moniker Madd Head, was shot and killed Sunday night in the parking lot of a market in Gardena.
item.content:encoded: Jerry Lewis, a popular 1990s rapper known by the moniker Madd Head, was shot and killed Sunday night in the parking lot of a market in Gardena.

media:content.media:description: Umeir Hawkins 38, left, and Sabrina Carter 50 of Los Angeles were charged with murder this week after a fight with a 50-year-old man who was not wearing a mask inside a Gardena market, according to the Los Angeles County District Attorney's office. Photo courtesy of the Gardena Police Department

item.title: Going back to college during a pandemic: Here's what you need to know
item.description: Last school year, you might have spent weeknights in a study room with poor circulation, surrounded by friends as you crammed for exams.
item.content:encoded: Last school year, you might have spent weeknights in a study room with poor circulation, surrounded by friends as you crammed for exams. Weekends probably included an outing to a bar, house show or party. And you might have lived in the quintessential on-campus dorm, where you shared everything (sometimes begrudgingly) with a roommate or two. If you're a rising freshman, you were probably looking forward to those experiences as you perfected your college essays and anxiously hoped for acceptance letters from your top schools.Then COVID-19 made its way into our lives. Students had to leave campuses. Classes went online. Graduations too.The 2020 fall semester is going to be very different for everyone. Here are some ways make the most out of it, whatever it looks like, and get a handle on some trickier issues and news updates.

media:content.media:description: FULLERTON-CA-APRIL 21, 2020: Cal State University Fullerton student Linh Trinh, 21, right, and her boyfriend Tan Nguyen, 21, walk around a deserted CSUF campus on Tuesday, April 21, 2020. The school is planning to begin Fall semester with online classes, one of the first universities in the nation to make that move as campuses throughout the country grapple with how long to stay closed to most students amid the coronavirus pandemic. (Christina House / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: California mobile home parks have lax oversight and few inspections, state audit warns

item.title: Death of Robert Fuller, found hanging from a tree in Palmdale, is ruled a suicide
item.dc:creator: Colleen Shalby, Matthew Ormseth
item.description: Sheriff's investigators have concluded that Robert Fuller, whose body was found hanging from a tree in Palmdale last month, died by suicide, saying a thorough investigation found no signs of foul play and showed the 24-year-old had previously expressed suicidal behavior.

media:content.media:description: CLAREMONT, CA - MARCH 28, 2020 - A jogger in face mask crosses a street in Pomona College on the morning of Friday March 27, 2020 in Claremont. A student of the college was diagnosed for COVID-19 on Tuesday and informed the school Wednesday, Pomona College announced Thursday night. The student, whose name was not released, left campus March 13 and has not returned, according to a statement from the college. (Irfan Khan / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Cannabis entrepreneurs agree to drop lawsuit over 'flawed' licensing process
item.dc:creator: Emily Alpert Reyes
item.description: Cannabis entrepreneurs agreed to drop a lawsuit over L.A.'s licensing process after the city agreed to consider more applicants vying to open new shops.

Dodger Stadium on Wednesday, July 8, 2020 in Los Angeles, CA. (Al Seib / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: California legislators delay return to Capitol as a lawmaker is hospitalized with COVID-19
item.dc:creator: Patrick McGreevy
item.description: The California Senate joined the Assembly in deciding not to return from its summer recess next week.
item.content:encoded: The California Senate joined the Assembly in deciding not to return from its summer recess next week.

media:content.media:description: The California Assembly casts votes on Thursday, Sept. 12, 2019 at the state Capitol in Sacramento.

item.title: UC President-elect Michael V. Drake knows firsthand about harsh police tactics
item.dc:creator: Teresa Watanabe
item.description: Michael V. Drake, the newly selected University of California president and the system's first Black leader, knows first-hand about disrespectful policing -- he's been stopped and searched multiple times -- and says it's time to stop such practices.
item.content:encoded: Michael V. Drake, the newly selected University of California president and the system's first Black leader, knows first-hand about disrespectful policing -- he's been stopped and searched multiple times -- and says it's time to stop such practices.

media:content.media:description: National Collegiate Athletic Association Board of Governors Chairman Dr. Michael Drake testifies before a Senate Commerce Committee hearing on Capitol Hill in Washington, Wednesday, July 1, 2020. The hearing is looking at the National Collegiate Athletic Association Board of Governors' recent report on student-athlete compensation and the modernization of rules related to name, image, and likeness commercialization. (AP Photo/Susan Walsh)

item.title: With demand soaring, L.A. County narrows priority for who should get coronavirus tests
item.dc:creator: Colleen Shalby
item.description: Priority will now be given to those showing symptoms, who work in a high-risk environment or who have come in contact with a person known to have been exposed to the virus.
item.content:encoded: Priority will now be given to those showing symptoms, who work in a high-risk environment or who have come in contact with a person known to have been exposed to the virus.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - JULY 08: Hundreds line up for COVID-19 testing in the parking lot at Dodger Stadium in the drone image on Wednesday, July 8, 2020 in Los Angeles, CA. (Brian van der Brug / Los Angeles Times)
media:content.media:credit: Brian van der Brug/Los Angeles Times

item.title: Newsom says reopening of California schools to be based on safety, not pressure from Trump
item.dc:creator: Patrick McGreevy
item.description: Gov. Gavin Newsom said Wednesday that the decision on reopening schools this fall will be made by local education and health officials and he does not feel pressured by statements from President Trump urging campuses to bring back students.
item.content:encoded: Gov. Gavin Newsom said Wednesday that the decision on reopening schools this fall will be made by local education and health officials and he does not feel pressured by statements from President Trump urging campuses to bring back students.

media:content.media:description: Gov. Gavin Newsom discusses his revised 2019-2020 state budget during a news conference Thursday, May 9, 2019, in Sacramento, Calif. Newsom, a Democrat, has proposed a $213.5 billion a spending plan. (AP Photo/Rich Pedroncelli)

item.title: John Swing, a driving force in L.A.'s Historic Filipinotown, dies of COVID-19 at 48
item.dc:creator: Tiffany Wong
item.description: Swing's death came just two months after he was asked to lead Search to Involve Pilipino Americans
item.content:encoded: Swing's death came just two months after he was asked to lead Search to Involve Pilipino Americans

item.title: Endangered California condors in Sequoia National Park for the first time in 50 years
item.dc:creator: Kailyn Brown
item.description: At least six of the giant birds were spotted in the park in late May, biologists said, a testament to the continued recovery of the species.
item.content:encoded: At least six of the giant birds were spotted in the park in late May, biologists said, a testament to the continued recovery of the species.

media:content.media:description: A condor in flight in Big Sur last summer. The new condor cam will help scientists monitor the birds -- and let the general public get a look at them in the wild well.

item.title: Coronavirus cases surge at Lake Tahoe amid summer tourist season
item.dc:creator: Rong-Gong Lin II, Sean Greene
item.description: The rate of new coronavirus infections is disproportionately high in the South Lake Tahoe region, a favorite California destination.
item.content:encoded: The rate of new coronavirus infections is disproportionately high in the South Lake Tahoe region, a favorite California destination.

media:content.media:description: FILE - In this Tuesday, Aug. 22, 2017, file photo, a family of ducks swims along the shore of South Lake Tahoe near the site of the 21st Annual Lake Tahoe Summit, in South Lake Tahoe, Calif. Voters in California could approve spending $127 million for projects in Lake Tahoe through a series of ballot measures in 2018. The California Clean Water and Safe Parks Act, which would approve $4.1 billion for spending, will be on the June 5 primary ballot. The Water Supply and Water Quality Act, for $8.9 billion, is scheduled for the Nov. 6 election. (AP Photo/Rich Pedroncelli, File)

item.title: Orange County leaves it up to restaurants to alert customers about coronavirus cases
item.dc:creator: Colleen Shalby
item.description: O.C. health department doesn't make public which restaurants and businesses have closed temporarily due to coronavirus cases.
item.content:encoded: O.C. health department doesn't make public which restaurants and businesses have closed temporarily due to coronavirus cases.

media:content.media:description: HUNTINGTON BEACH, CA - JULY 01: A classic convertible passes by patrons dining at restaurants and bars on Main Street Wednesday, July 1, 2020 in Huntington Beach, CA. Bars across Orange County, many of which have only recently reopened, will be forced to shut down again beginning at midnight Thursday, Gov. Newsom announced. County officials on Wednesday announced the closure of bars, pubs, breweries and brewpubs that do not offer dine-in meals amid a troubling surge in coronavirus cases that has resulted in an increased hospitalization rate and the placement of the county on Gov. Gavin Newsom's watch list. (Allen J. Schaben / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: San Francisco lawmaker proposes CAREN Act, making racially biased 911 calls illegal
item.dc:creator: Jake Sheridan
item.description: CAREN would designate discriminatory bogus police calls as hate crimes and provide civil remedy for victims, Supervisor Shamann Walton says.
item.content:encoded: CAREN would designate discriminatory bogus police calls as hate crimes and provide civil remedy for victims, Supervisor Shamann Walton says.

media:content.media:description: SAN FRANCISCO, CA - JUNE 26, 2019 - San Francisco Supervisor Shamann Walton stands on Topeka Avenue near the former home of his great-aunt in the Bayview District of San Francisco on June 26, 2019. He still lives in the Bayview District and spent many holidays at the homes on Topeka Ave. and another, on Apollo St. in the Bayview District owned by his great-aunts. After his great-aunts died, their adult children sold the houses during the tech-fueled real estate boom and Walton?s family scattered to Sacramento and the far East Bay communities of Vallejo and Antioch. The loss of those physical anchors, so full of childhood memories, is devastating, said Walton. ?Not having that family connection, not having that place where people gathered for decades? to lose that is reflective of what?s happening across San Francisco.? (Genaro Molina/Los Angeles Times) ATTENTION PRE-PRESS; PLEASE DO NOT LIGHTEN. PLEASE MAINTAIN TONE. THANKS.

item.title: California sets record for most coronavirus cases in a single day
item.dc:creator: Hannah Fry, Colleen Shalby
item.description: California cases are on pace to double every 24.8 days, a number that is used by experts to measure how quickly the virus is spreading.
item.content:encoded: California cases are on pace to double every 24.8 days, a number that is used by experts to measure how quickly the virus is spreading.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - JUNE 25: People wait in line to have a Covid-19 screening administered by the Community Organized Relief Effort at the Los Angeles City Mayor's Covid-19 test site at Dodger Stadium on Thursday, June 25, 2020 in Los Angeles, CA. The line of traffic is shown leading up to the entrance of Dodger Stadium at Stadium Way and Scott. 6000 people had registered for the coronavirus screening for today. (Gary Coronado / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Coronavirus spike jeopardizes opening of schools, L.A. County's top health official warns
item.dc:creator: Howard Blume, Eli Stokols
item.description: Public and private schools must prepare for students to continue learning remotely, L.A.County public health director tells superintendents.
item.content:encoded: Public and private schools must prepare for students to continue learning remotely, L.A.County public health director tells superintendents.

media:content.media:description: GLENDALE, CA - MAY 26: Principal Perla Chavez-Fritz, left, of Cerritos Elementary in Glendale and Los Angeles County Office of Education Supt. Debra Duardo, right, tour of Cerritos Elementary in Glendale on Tuesday May 26, 2020 considering that with a persisting coronavirus threat, K-12 campuses will try to reopen in the fall. New L.A. County guidelines offer a possible roadmap but it could get complicated and costly to confront the logistics of reopening at an actual school in the wake of Covid-19. Glendale on Tuesday, May 26, 2020 in Glendale, CA. (Al Seib / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Commentary: A fitting end to the last Confederate monument in Southern California
item.dc:creator: Christopher Knight
item.description: An 800-pound marker for the Jefferson Davis National Highway has been removed from view. A college student's email prompted the change.
item.content:encoded: An 800-pound marker for the Jefferson Davis National Highway has been removed from view. A college student's email prompted the change.

media:content.media:description: The 800-lb. Jefferson Davis National Highway marker was installed in Kern County in 1942

item.title: Andres Guardado was shot five times in the back, family autopsy finds. Deputy's lawyer defends shooting
item.dc:creator: Alene Tchekmedyian
item.description: Attorneys say an independent autopsy has found Andres Guardado was shot five times in the back when he was killed by a deputy in Gardena last month.
item.content:encoded: Attorneys say an independent autopsy has found Andres Guardado was shot five times in the back when he was killed by a deputy in Gardena last month.

media:content.media:description: GARDENA, CA - JUNE 28: Relatives of Andres Guardado, who was fatally shot by a sheriff's deputy in Gardena, and civil rights activists participate in rally seeking justice for Andres Guardado on Sunday, June 28, 2020 in Gardena, CA. (Jason Armond / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: International students upended, unsure if they can continue U.S. studies amid new federal rules
item.dc:creator: Nina Agrawal, Tiffany Wong, Elliot Wailoo

item.content:encoded: A day after international students attending classes online were told they would not be allowed in the U.S., students expressed disbelief and fear.

media:content.media:description: UCLA edged out USC in U.S. News & World Report's annual list of university rankings. UCLA placed 23rd, tied with the University of Virginia. Crosstown rival USC tied for 25th place with Carnegie Mellon University.

item.title: Fireworks went up and dogs ran out: L.A. pups lost, found and returned after the Fourth

item.description: The Fourth of July is one of the busiest nights of the year for L.A. animal shelters.
item.content:encoded: The Fourth of July is one of the busiest nights of the year for L.A. animal shelters.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CALIFORNIA JULY 7, 2020-A pit bull mix stands outside the Chesterfield Square animal sheler in South Los Angeles. The dog was found Sunday morning the day after Fourth of July celebrations. (Wally Skalij/Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Column: She asked her neighbors to wear masks. Then the swastikas and racial slurs appeared
item.dc:creator: Sandy Banks
item.description: Worried about the spread of the coronavirus, a Canoga Park woman asked her apartment neighbors to wear masks. Then, racist scrawls appeared in the elevator.
item.content:encoded: Worried about the spread of the coronavirus, a Canoga Park woman asked her apartment neighbors to wear masks. Then, racist scrawls appeared in the elevator.

media:content.media:description: CANOGA PARK, CA - JULY 05: Jaycebelle Tadena, 29, of Canoga Park poses for a portrait at her apartment where she found swastikas and racial slurs painted on the inside the elevator at her apartment in on Sunday, July 5, 2020 in Canoga Park, CA. (Jason Armond / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: As decision looms on reopening schools, LAUSD sticks with four-time board president
item.dc:creator: Howard Blume
item.description: Faced with the challenges of the coronavirus outbreak — including a decision on reopening campuses — LAUSD board members put aside policy differences to reelect Richard Vladovic as their president.
item.content:encoded: Faced with the challenges of the coronavirus outbreak — including a decision on reopening campuses — LAUSD board members put aside policy differences to reelect Richard Vladovic as their president.

media:content.media:description: School Board President Richard Vladovic at a meeting in October. He and board colleagues announced Tuesday's vote alongside union leaders.

item.title: Column: This is the only California county that's coronavirus-free. Masks are optional
item.dc:creator: Erika D. Smith
item.description: Not wearing a face mask is reckless. But in a weird way, it seems a little less so in Modoc County, which hasn't had a single case of the coronavirus.
item.content:encoded: Not wearing a face mask is reckless. But in a weird way, it seems a little less so in Modoc County, which hasn't had a single case of the coronavirus.

media:content.media:description: Modoc County Sheriff Tex Dowdy prepares for the annual Fourth of July Parade in July 2020. It's tradition that sheriff lead the parade on horseback behind the color guard.

item.title: Many in Orange County resist masks even as coronavirus cases soar

item.description: Public health experts say wearing a mask can prevent the spread of COVID-19, but in Orange County many are still skeptical.
item.content:encoded: Public health experts say wearing a mask can prevent the spread of COVID-19, but in Orange County many are still skeptical.

Bars across Orange County, many of which have only recently reopened, will be forced to shut down again beginning at midnight Thursday, officials announced. County officials on Wednesday announced the closure of bars, pubs, breweries and brewpubs that do not offer dine-in meals amid a troubling surge in coronavirus cases that has resulted in an increased hospitalization rate and the placement of the county on Gov. Gavin Newsom's watch list. (Allen J. Schaben / Los Angeles Times)

item.content:encoded: A significant number of residents believe California reopened its economy too early and are worried they could get COVID-19 as cases once again surge.

media:content.media:description: Los Angeles, CA, Sunday, June 28,2020 - Patrons of the Down'n'Out Sports Bar, drink at an outside patio. Governor Newsom orders bars to close as Covid-19 cases surge in California. (Robert Gauthier / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Riverside County surpasses 20,000 coronavirus cases. That wasn't supposed to happen yet
item.dc:creator: Kristi Sturgill
item.description: Riverside County saw its COVID-19 numbers increase after Memorial Day. Officials say it's a harbinger for a case influx following the Fourth of July
item.content:encoded: Riverside County saw its COVID-19 numbers increase after Memorial Day. Officials say it's a harbinger for a case influx following the Fourth of July

media:content.media:description: RIVERSIDE, CA- APRIL 8, 2020: Bernie Erwig, 84, is removed from Magnolia Rehabilitation and Nursing Center after 39 tested positive for coronavirus and nursing staff was not showing up to work for their own safety on April 8, 2020 in Riverside, California. All 84 residents were removed. Erwig tested positive for COVID-19 and was transferred to the county hospital in Moreno Valley, RUHS, where he spent 4 weeks recovering from the coronavirus. He is now home still recuperating. (Gina Ferazzi / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: LAPD investigates 'blue flu' claims after officers call in sick over July 4 holiday

item.content:encoded: LAPD officials are investigating whether a spike in officers calling in sick over the July 4 weekend was the result of an orchestrated protest.

item.title: Michael V. Drake named new UC president, first Black leader in system's 152-year history

President Obama's address kicks off the campus's 50th anniversary celebration.The first speaker was President Lyndon Johnson, who dedicated the site of the future University of California institution on June 20, 1964. (Irfan Khan / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Hot, windy weather ahead as Soledad fire mop-up continues
item.dc:creator: Luke Money
item.description: Officials warn that hot temperatures, low relative humidities, locally gusty winds and drying fuels will bring elevated fire weather conditions.
item.content:encoded: Officials warn that hot temperatures, low relative humidities, locally gusty winds and drying fuels will bring elevated fire weather conditions.

media:content.media:description: AGUA DULCE, CA - JULY 06: Los Angeles County Firefighters Justin Corrales, left, and Jason Torres, right, with Captain August Dougherty, center, extinguish flare-ups as the temperatures rose Monday morning along Agua Dulce Canyon Road as Firefighters work to contain the Soledad Fire Monday morning a day after the brush fire had scorched up to 1,500 acres near the Antelope Valley (14) Freeway north off Santa Clarita but its forward progress has been stopped overnight. The blaze possibly sparked by illegal fireworks had nearly 400 firefighters working overnight to put out flames and clear lines of vegetation to contain them. Fames threatened nine homes in rural Escondido and Agua Dulce Canyon's which were ordered evacuated. Escondido Canyon on Monday, July 6, 2020 in Agua Dulce, CA. (Al Seib / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: A California sheriff mocked the state's stay-at-home order. He changed his tune when COVID-19 cases surged
item.dc:creator: Hailey Branson-Potts
item.description: Merced County, where the sheriff questioned the pandemic and a town became a 'sanctuary city for business,' is now on the state watchlist after a surge in COVID-19 cases.
item.content:encoded: Merced County, where the sheriff questioned the pandemic and a town became a 'sanctuary city for business,' is now on the state watchlist after a surge in COVID-19 cases.

media:content.media:description: ATWATER, CA - MAY 26, 2020 - - Atwater City Council members John Cale, from left, Danny Ambriz, City Manager Lori Waterman, and Mayor Pro Tem and City Council member Brian Raymond bow their heads during the invocation at the start of a city council meeting in Atwater on May 26, 2020. The city of Atwater in Merced County has declared itself a "sanctuary city" from the state's stay-at-home orders and has been open for business for over a week now. (Genaro Molina / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Former L.A. Councilman Mitchell Englander pleads guilty in City Hall corruption case

item.content:encoded: Former L.A. City Councilman Mitchell Englander pleaded guilty Tuesday, becoming the third figure to do so in a City Hall corruption inquiry.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA. JULY 7, 2020 -- Former Los Angeles city councilman Mitch Englander, right, arrives at the Federal Courthouse in downtown Los Angeles with life wife, Jayne, daughters, Lauren, left and Lindsey, Tuesday morning July 7, 2020.

item.title: Shelter-in-place order lifted at Twentynine Palms Marine Corps base after active shooter reports
item.dc:creator: Luke Money
item.description: One person suffered a self-inflicted gunshot wound around 8:30 a.m., and no other injuries were reported, officials said in a statement.
item.content:encoded: One person suffered a self-inflicted gunshot wound around 8:30 a.m., and no other injuries were reported, officials said in a statement.

media:content.media:description: JUNE 8, 2011. 29 PALMS MARINE CORPS BASE, CA. Twentynine Palms Marine combat training base logistics area where maneuvers originate. Over the distant horizon and adjacent to the base is Johnson Valley off road recreation area. A recent compromise between the Marine Corps and the off road lobby will enable the Marines to share the area for 2 months a year. (Don Bartletti / Los Angeles Times)

item.content:encoded: For the first time, Orange County reported more than 1,000 new COVID-19 cases in a single day, with young adults accounting for most new infections.

Bars across Orange County, many of which have only recently reopened, will be forced to shut down again beginning at midnight Thursday, Gov. Newsom announced. County officials on Wednesday announced the closure of bars, pubs, breweries and brewpubs that do not offer dine-in meals amid a troubling surge in coronavirus cases that has resulted in an increased hospitalization rate and the placement of the county on Gov. Gavin Newsom's watch list. (Allen J. Schaben / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: As protests against police brutality go global, these Latina moms fight in memory of their sons
item.dc:creator: Esmeralda Bermudez
item.description: In East L.A., 15 moms who have lost their sons to law enforcement killings unite against abusive police tactics.
item.content:encoded: In East L.A., 15 moms who have lost their sons to law enforcement killings unite against abusive police tactics.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA-JUNE 25, 2020--Teresa Dominguez, left, and Rosa Morena, right, hug each other at a Black Lives Matter rally after the story of their son's deaths at the hands of law enforcement were told. Teresa Dominguez lost her son Jesse Romero, on 8/9/2016, while Rosa Morena lost her son Cesar Rodriguez on 8/29/2017. Latina mother's whose sons were killed by law enforcement in the past few years speak out at a Black Lives Matter protest in from of the Hall of Justice in downtown Los Angeles on June 24, 2020. They are fighting against police brutality and asking for the removal of Jackie Lacey. (Carolyn Cole/Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Reopening L.A. economy improved mental health, but coronavirus fears persist, survey finds
item.dc:creator: Rong-Gong Lin II, Colleen Shalby
item.description: The results of a survey by the USC Dornsife Center for Economic and Social Research were revealed Monday amid a major increase in new coronavirus cases and hospitalizations.
item.content:encoded: The results of a survey by the USC Dornsife Center for Economic and Social Research were revealed Monday amid a major increase in new coronavirus cases and hospitalizations.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - JULY 01, 2020 - - Waiter Pedro Armenta, wearing a face shield and mask, checks the temperature of customer Julian Bourely before entering Dupar's Restaurant which is still receiving customers for patio dining and take-out service at the Original Farmers Market in the Fairfax District in Los Angeles on July 1, 2020. All customers have to wear masks and have their temperature read before being allowed into the eatery. California Governor Gavin Newsom ordered indoor restaurants closed effective immediately on July 1, 2020. (Genaro Molina / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: California braces for a spike in coronavirus deaths as infections soar. But how bad will it be?
item.dc:creator: Alex Wigglesworth, Anita Chabria, Emily Baumgaertner, Rong-Gong Lin II
item.description: Now, public health officials are bracing for the grimmest phase of the cycle: a spike in COVID-19 fatalities.
item.content:encoded: Now, public health officials are bracing for the grimmest phase of the cycle: a spike in COVID-19 fatalities.

media:content.media:description: The boardwalk in Mission Beach was full of holiday locals, surfers and tourist during the Fourth of July holiday in San Diego. Because of the coronavirus pandemic the typical holiday crowd appears to be less than previous years.
media:content.media:credit: Nelvin C. Cepeda / The San Diego Union-Tribune

item.title: These doctors brought a shuttered L.A. hospital back to life to fight coronavirus
item.dc:creator: Thomas Curwen
item.description: The L.A. Surge Hospital treated a small number of coronavirus patients during the 39 days it was open. But doctors say it saved 'many, many lives,' while restoring their faith in medicine.
item.content:encoded: The L.A. Surge Hospital treated a small number of coronavirus patients during the 39 days it was open. But doctors say it saved 'many, many lives,' while restoring their faith in medicine.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - APRIL 13: St. Vincent Medical Center located at 2131 West 3rd st. in Los Angeles is back in business to help ease the pressure on local hospitals amid the novel coronavirus pandemic. Staff set up beds and other equipment ready to receive patients with Covid-19 starting Monday. The 266-bed facility will serve as a hospital accepting patients that have tested positive at a different regional hospital that may be at capacity. Los Angeles on Monday, April 13, 2020 in Los Angeles, CA. (Al Seib / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Young adults who think 'they are invincible' increasingly infected by coronavirus, Newsom says
item.dc:creator: Rong-Gong Lin II, Colleen Shalby, Sandhya Kambhampati, Iris Lee
item.description: Gov. Gavin Newsom said Monday said the surge in coronavirus cases hitting California was due in part to younger people who might believe "they are invincible" but nonetheless are becoming sick from COVID-19.
item.content:encoded: Gov. Gavin Newsom said Monday said the surge in coronavirus cases hitting California was due in part to younger people who might believe "they are invincible" but nonetheless are becoming sick from COVID-19.

media:content.media:description: MANHATTAN BEACH, CA - JULY 06: A light crowd enjoys the sand and surf at Manhattan Beach on Monday, July 6, 2020 following the three-day Fourth of July weekend. (Myung J. Chun / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: 13-year-old girl killed in violent carjacking of family van in Pico Rivera
item.dc:creator: Kailyn Brown
item.description: The teen was one of four children inside the vehicle when a man jumped in and sped off.
item.content:encoded: The teen was one of four children inside the vehicle when a man jumped in and sped off.

media:content.media:description: Isabella Cortes, 13, died during a violent carjacking in Pico Rivera Sunday July 5, 2020..

item.title: As coronavirus cases surge, L.A. County death toll tops 3,500
item.dc:creator: Colleen Shalby
item.description: The city-run testing facility at Dodger Stadium was closed Monday. City officials were not immediately available to comment on whether it would be reopened.
item.content:encoded: The city-run testing facility at Dodger Stadium was closed Monday. City officials were not immediately available to comment on whether it would be reopened.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - JUNE 30, Shoppers, wearing masks to protect themselves from coronavirus, shop on Santee Alley in the Garment District in downtown Los Angeles on June 30, 2020. Masks are required for shopping on Santee Alley and social distancing is advised, but hard to enforce. The shopping area has been open again for the past three weeks. (Genaro Molina / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Top medical officer for California prisons ousted amid worsening coronavirus outbreak
item.dc:creator: Richard Winton, Kim Christensen
item.description: The move comes amid criticism over the transfer of hundreds of inmates to prisons from a Chino facility reeling from coronavirus infections.
item.content:encoded: The move comes amid criticism over the transfer of hundreds of inmates to prisons from a Chino facility reeling from coronavirus infections.

media:content.media:description: Schaben, Allen J.   CHINO: AUG. 10, 2009: As viewed through the afternoon heat waves, a corrections officer looks out from a tower over barbed wire fences and transport busses at the California Institution For Men State Prison in Chino. California prisons remain on lockdown after Saturday's riot in Chino. On Aug. 8 a violent riot broke out at the California Institution of Men in the West reception facility. About 200 inmates were injured and 30 remain hospitalized with nonlife threatening injuries. Some say the riot is a result of racerelated tensions between Blacks and Latinos.(Allen J. Schaben / Los Angeles Times
media:content.media:credit: Allen J. Schaben / Los Angeles Times

item.title: Newsom, coming under fire, ramps up enforcement and adds counties to watchlist
item.dc:creator: Phil Willon
item.description: Newsom vows to crack down on restaurants and bars that ignored restrictions over the July 4 weekend. Some critics say it is too little, too late.
item.content:encoded: Newsom vows to crack down on restaurants and bars that ignored restrictions over the July 4 weekend. Some critics say it is too little, too late.

media:content.media:description: Gov. Gavin Newsom discusses his plan for the gradual reopening of California businesses during a news conference at the Display California store in Sacramento, Calif., Tuesday, May 5, 2020. Newsom warned counties that going too far in loosening coronavirus restrictions, could endanger public health. Display California, which sells locally-made items from around the state, is planning to open for curbside service on Friday under upcoming state guidelines. (AP Photo/Rich Pedroncelli, Pool)

item.title: L.A. lawmaker tests positive for COVID-19, forcing delay of Assembly legislative session
item.dc:creator: Melody Gutierrez
item.description: California's state Capitol is closed, and its Assembly leader is delaying hearings after Assemblywoman Autumn Burke and four others test positive for the coronavirus.
item.content:encoded: California's state Capitol is closed, and its Assembly leader is delaying hearings after Assemblywoman Autumn Burke and four others test positive for the coronavirus.

media:content.media:description: SACRAMENTO CA SEPTEMBER 9, 2019 -- Assemblywoman Autumn Burke (D-Marina del Rey) confers with a colleague during floor debate at the state Capitol on Aug. 29, 2019. (Robert Gourley / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Gimme Shelter: Why it's still really expensive to buy a home in California
item.dc:creator: Liam Dillon
item.description: Neither home prices nor rents have gone down significantly in California despite double-digit unemployment.
item.content:encoded: Neither home prices nor rents have gone down significantly in California despite double-digit unemployment.

media:content.media:description: A home in Palo Alto. Pending sales of previously owned homes rose 21.8% in the Midwest, 9.2% in the South and 9% in the Northeast in February, but fell 4.8% in the West in February, according to the National Assn. of Realtors.

item.title: Crews fire near Gilroy destroys two homes, chars 5,400 acres
item.dc:creator: Luke Money
item.description: The Crews fire ignited about 11:30 a.m. Sunday near Highway 152 in Gilroy and forced dozens of residents to evacuate.
item.content:encoded: The Crews fire ignited about 11:30 a.m. Sunday near Highway 152 in Gilroy and forced dozens of residents to evacuate.

media:content.media:description: A wildfire that broke out Sunday has burned 2,000 acres and destroyed two homes near Gilroy.

item.title: Beaches reopen in L.A., Ventura counties after holiday weekend closure
item.dc:creator: Colleen Shalby
item.description: Beaches in Los Angeles and Ventura counties were closed for three days in an effort to keep crowds away amid the growing coronavirus outbreak.
item.content:encoded: Beaches in Los Angeles and Ventura counties were closed for three days in an effort to keep crowds away amid the growing coronavirus outbreak.

media:content.media:description: SANTA MONICA, CA - JULY 06: Peter Gratzinger of Pacific Palisades works his way to the water at Santa Monica State Beach which opened to the public at 5 a.m. Monday, July 6, 2020 after being closed for the three-day Fourth of July weekend. (Myung J. Chun / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Soledad fire evacuations lifted as firefighters gain upper hand
item.dc:creator: Luke Money
item.description: The fire that began around Soledad Canyon Road and the 14 Freeway on Sunday was about 30% contained as of 9 a.m., the L.A. County Fire Department said.
item.content:encoded: The fire that began around Soledad Canyon Road and the 14 Freeway on Sunday was about 30% contained as of 9 a.m., the L.A. County Fire Department said.

media:content.media:description: Firefighter hand crews from Azusa Camp 19 climb the hills to put in line containing the Soledad Fire near Aqua Dulce Monday morning.

item.title: 'All he saw to me was my skin color': Clerk faces backlash from judge's comment
item.dc:creator: Matt Hamilton
item.description: Chief judge's comment on race roil court,
item.content:encoded: Chief judge's comment on race roil court,

media:content.media:description: SAN JUAN CAPISTRANO, CALIF. -- TUESDAY, AUGUST 21, 2018: Photo of U.S. District Judge Cormac J. Carney, 59, a former receiver at UCLA 1980 to 1982, in San Juan Capistrano, Calif., on Aug. 21, 2018. (Gary Coronado / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Women say they were groped, violated by police during L.A. curfew arrests
item.dc:creator: Kevin Rector
item.description: Among the ranks of protesters who have filed complaints, joined lawsuits and pushed back against tactics used by area police agencies are women who say they were groped, sexually harassed or inappropriately searched.
item.content:encoded: Among the ranks of protesters who have filed complaints, joined lawsuits and pushed back against tactics used by area police agencies are women who say they were groped, sexually harassed or inappropriately searched.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - JULY 05: Portrait of Julia Dupuis, 21, near the corner of 8th and Crenshaw on Sunday, July 5, 2020 in Los Angeles, CA. Julia Dupuis says a LAPD officer groped her as she was being arrested on a curfew violation June 2nd. She and others had been participating in a demstration. (Francine Orr / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: California coronavirus spikes worsen over holiday weekend
item.dc:creator: Rong-Gong Lin II, Maria L. La Ganga, Kristi Sturgill
item.description: In Los Angeles County, officials said the holiday weekend saw the highest single-day count of new cases since the pandemic began: 3,200 on Friday.
item.content:encoded: In Los Angeles County, officials said the holiday weekend saw the highest single-day count of new cases since the pandemic began: 3,200 on Friday.

media:content.media:description: VENICE, CA - JULY 05, 2020 - - People walk along the Venice Boardwalk in Venice on July 5, 2020. In what officials have described as an "alarming" increase, hospitalizations of patients with confirmed coronavirus infections in Los Angeles County have jumped 41% in the last three weeks. On Friday, there were 1,947 patients in L.A. County hospitals with confirmed coronavirus infections; seven days earlier, there were 1,717; the week before that, there were 1,426; and the week prior to that, there were 1,383. (Genaro Molina / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: L.A. County coronavirus cases hit a record one-day high heading into July 4 weekend
item.dc:creator: Laura Newberry
item.description: The number of hospital patients with confirmed coronavirus infections jumped 41% in the last three weeks in Los Angeles County.
item.content:encoded: The number of hospital patients with confirmed coronavirus infections jumped 41% in the last three weeks in Los Angeles County.

media:content.media:description: UNIVERSAL CITY, CA - JULY 02: A family wearing mask at Universal City Walk Hollywood on Thursday, July 2, 2020 in Universal City, CA. There was very few guests. Gov. Gavin Newsom on Wednesday ordered tougher restrictions on indoor activities for most of the state due to increase in coronavirus cases. (Gary Coronado / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Soledad fire burns 1,100 acres, but firefighters make progress
item.dc:creator: Laura Newberry
item.description: In Santa Clarita, a brushfire that broke out near Soledad Canyon Road jumped the 14 Freeway around 4 p.m. Within hours it had spread to 1,100 acres.
item.content:encoded: In Santa Clarita, a brushfire that broke out near Soledad Canyon Road jumped the 14 Freeway around 4 p.m. Within hours it had spread to 1,100 acres.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES COUNTY, CA - JULY 05: An L.A. County Fire Department helicopter prepares for a water drop on a brushfire burning along the 14 freeway in Agua Dulce on Sunday, July 5, 2020 in Los Angeles County, CA. No structures were threatened so far. (Myung J. Chun / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Hit-and-run driver kills man who tripped in street after lighting firework, police say
item.dc:creator: Alex Wigglesworth
item.description: A man was struck and killed in a hit-and-run crash Saturday in Lennox when he tripped in the street after lighting a firework, police said.
item.content:encoded: A man was struck and killed in a hit-and-run crash Saturday in Lennox when he tripped in the street after lighting a firework, police said.

item.title: L.A.'s extreme fireworks bring terrible air quality, increased calls for fire service
item.dc:creator: Alex Wigglesworth
item.description: Despite a ban on Fourth of July fireworks displays due to the coronavirus, L.A. firefighters responded to thousands of emergency calls on Saturday.
item.content:encoded: Despite a ban on Fourth of July fireworks displays due to the coronavirus, L.A. firefighters responded to thousands of emergency calls on Saturday.

media:content.media:description: BURBANK, CA - JULY 04: Fireworks over North Hollywood, as seen from Burbank on Saturday, July 4, 2020 in Burbank, CA. (Kent Nishimura / Los Angeles Times)
